awd_titl_txt: REU Site: Quantum and Materials Physics
awd_abstract_narration:
This award supports a new Research Experience for Undergraduates (REU) site in physics at Montana State University. The site will support eight students for ten weeks of summer research per year in cutting edge Quantum and Materials Physics topics. Their work will advance current research knowledge and contribute to publishable results and presentations at scientific conferences. Proposed REU research projects will be well defined and flexible to help ensure completion of the research in the ten-week period.  Students will gain unique technical skills and REU experience will inform their future education and career decisions. 

Student participants will be guided in research projects closely associated with ongoing research activities in Quantum Information Science and other Quantum Physics projects and teamed with experienced researchers who will mentor them during the program. Weekly meetings will be used to develop an awareness of ethical conduct in science, current research, the importance of science in society, and career opportunities in science and engineering. These meetings will also be used to develop communication skills and will foster additional periods of interaction among the REU students and MSU faculty mentors. Assessment will be exercised throughout the program to make certain that each participant is appropriately mentored and reaches their goals. This project is jointly funded by the Division of Physics and the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR) program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For the summers of 2021, 2023, and 2023 Montana State University (MSU) hosted 8, 10, and 8 undergraduate students, respectively, from other colleges and universities for 10 weeks to enable their participation in a Research Experience for Undergraduate (REU) program focused on Quantum and Materials Physics. The participants were from colleges and universities that were not research intensive institutions. Each was provided with a faculty mentor and integrated into a research group. Daily mentoring was shared among faculty, research scientists, postdoctoral researchers, and graduate students. The participants learned laboratory and theoretical skills associated with 6 different areas of quantum physics research through hands-on participation in research. They also honed scientific communication skills. The participants attended a weekly meeting with the principal investigators, which was used to gauge their progress and integration into research activities. They also attended a weekly seminar that was given by MSU scientists dealing with Quantum and Materials Physics and a seminar provided by our graduate admissions personnel to explain the process for applying to graduate school in STEM fields.  

By directly engaging the 26 participating students in Quantum and Materials Physics research, they made contributions at the forefront of science while simultaneously developing a better grasp of science and career pathways in science. The experience will inform their future decisions.

One REU project resulted in a new device for measuring the thermal expansion of solids and was reported in Review of Scientific Instruments (RSI). Two REU students worked towards a new method of selectively loading particles into a magneto-gravitational trap, described in a paper which has also been published in RSI. Another two students contributed to a novel method of real-time image analysis used to track the motion of particles, resulting in a paper which has been accepted for publication in RSI.

One of our REU students from 2021 and another from 2022 received NSF Graduate Research Fellowship Awards (NSF-GRFP). Our REU program had three Native American, once Pacific Islander, one Hispanic, and four female participants. That is 35% participation from STEM under-represented groups.
